Previously, ncteisen (Noah Eisen) wrote…
What about the case where channel A's trace references channel B. Then channel B is destroyed. We want the channelz and channel trace info for B to live as long as it is referenced from A. Can that be accomplished with InternallyRefCounted? I explicitly set the destroyed bit so that one can still render the JSON for a channelz whose channel no longer exists
I don't see why this would be a problem. The only real differences between `RefCounted<>` and `InternallyRefCounted<>` are (a) who has access to call `Ref()` and `Unref()` and (b) with `InternallyRefCounted<>`, the `Orphan()` method provides a hook to take special action when the external reference is released. Any constraints on the lifetime of the object are orthogonal to that choice; whatever you want the object's lifetime to be, you can make that happen with either one. I think the grey area here is that the intent of `InternallyRefCounted<>` is that the internal refs come from inside the same *object*, but what the compiler actually enforces is that the internal refs come from the same *class*. So what I'm proposing here is to make use of that distinction: when channel A's trace wants to reference channel B's trace, it will grab a reference to channel B. If the code to do that is inside of the `channelz::Channel` class, then it should work fine, even though the ref is coming from a different instance of the same class. If the ref winds up needing to come from the channel trace object instead of from the channelz object, then maybe we should reevaluate what the relationship is between the two. For example, could the channel trace class be a nested class within the channelz class? If there's no reasonable way to make this work, the current approach isn't the end of the world. But if we can find a way to make this more structurally automatic, I think that would be better. --- *[src/core/lib/surface/call.cc, line 1264 at r7](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15343#-LER5dnFBwJi_BwcDtlK:-LER5dnFBwJi_BwcDtlL:b-rttz24) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/70f7558a18fd92320813b6ba4107b94c83cc7b0b/src/core/lib/surface/call.cc#L1264)):* > ```cpp > } > > if (call->channel != nullptr) { > ``` I still don't see how this can be false. The only real differences between `RefCounted<>` and `InternallyRefCounted<>` are (a) who has access to call `Ref()` and `Unref()` and (b) with `InternallyRefCounted<>`, the `Orphan()` method provides a hook to take special action when the external reference is released. Any constraints on the lifetime of the object are orthogonal to that choice; whatever you want the object's lifetime to be, you can make that happen with either one. I think the grey area here is that the intent of `InternallyRefCounted<>` is that the internal refs come from inside the same *object*, but what the compiler actually enforces is that the internal refs come from the same *class*. So what I'm proposing here is to make use of that distinction: when channel A's trace wants to reference channel B's trace, it will grab a reference to channel B. If the code to do that is inside of the `channelz::Channel` class, then it should work fine, even though the ref is coming from a different instance of the same class. If the ref winds up needing to come from the channel trace object instead of from the channelz object, then maybe we should reevaluate what the relationship is between the two. For example, could the channel trace class be a nested class within the channelz class? If there's no reasonable way to make this work, the current approach isn't the end of the world. But if we can find a way to make this more structurally automatic, I think that would be better.
Currently, the owner of the ref to channel B, would be the individual trace events in the channel trace for channel A. That way more than one trace event can reference B, and then only when ALL of them have been overwritten in the trace object is B removed. So I think this will only work if we nest channel trace inside channel. I am a little hesitant to do that because I think that the soon-to-come shadow objects, like Subchannel and Server will want to have ChannelTrace inside of them too. --- *[src/core/lib/surface/call.cc, line 1264 at r7](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15343#-LER5dnFBwJi_BwcDtlK:-LERkDPP3Ltx3dcyRPvi:bkia0m5) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/70f7558a18fd92320813b6ba4107b94c83cc7b0b/src/core/lib/surface/call.cc#L1264)):*
